captions.text:
What’s good padna? This week we
gettin fu**ed by the Man with Catch- 22 by
Joseph Heller.

It’s World War II, playa, and some
soulja boy named Yosarrian just set up shop

on the island of Pianosa. Yosarrian and his
crew always cruisin round in their G-Fo droppin

BOMBS on suckas. But Yossarian don’t give
a sh** about the war, this cat just tryin

to come out the other side with his nuts in
tact.

Since a bunch of crooked-ass
bureaucrats running the show, makin it home

ain’t gonna be easy. Yo- money was s’posed
to only fly a certain number of missions before

he can head back to his hood. But every time
he hits the mark, some ignant-ass colonel
named Cathcart re-ups the number.

Turns out there’s only one way for
Yosarrian and his boys to stay off their bomb-droppin

grind: they gotta be whacked out in the head.
So if you crazy, all you gotta do is say so

and the military will send yo ass home. Ain’t
no thang, right?

Well there’s a catch, son- an
unwritten law called Catch-22. If you straight

enough to be like “Say, brah. Im crazy.
Get me outta here,” then you ain’t ACTUALLY

crazy. To these shysti hustlas, just tryin
to save yo own ass is proof enough that ain’t

nothin wrong with yo mind. So no matter what,
these soldiers gotta keep marchin.

By the end, Yo-seezy seen da war
put all his homies six feet deep- Clevinger,

Kid Sampson, McWatt, Dunbar, Nately- even
his roommate Orr who crashing his planes on
the reg.

But it ain’t til he sees his boy Snowden
get iced that everything changes for Yo-yo.

After watchin
snow-baby’s guts get splattered all up on

his threadz, he realize that life is way more
important than some bunk-ass war.

Well turns out Yo-dawg’s roomie Orr
flowin the same rhyme. Erryone thought he

was dead, but on the real, this fool actually
PRACTICED crashing his plane, and now he kickin
back up in Sweden. Gangsta!

So Yosarrian be all like “Man.
fu**. This. So long suckas. Sweden it is!”
Yosarrian lives, B!

Harper Lee once called Catch-22
“the only war novel [she’d] ever read

that makes any sense.” Now you might be
wonderin “What the hell was that girl smokin?”

This book confusing as sh**! Everything’s
outta order, the same unrealistic jive keeps

happening over and over, and the hell is up
with all these fancy words?

Well this literary OG wouldn’t have
it any other way. Catch-22 is absurd and confusing
cuz we live in an absurd and confusing world.

So if you feel like you gettin
burned just tryin to make sense of this mess,
you feelin just like our man Yossarian.

This cat gotta throw down with
shysti capitalists, bent-ass bureaucrats,

stuck-up psychiatrists, and people he don’t
even know who wanna bust a cap in his ass!

Fool stuck in a crooked system that got him
by the balls in the worst way:

Life can wreck even the hardest playas on
the block, and nothin

does it faster than havin to take on a faceless
evil. How’s a brotha gonna step to something
he can’t even see?

Yeah this book got a assload of villains-
but none of em badder

than Death itself. When Yo-sizzle peeps Snowden
get straight LIT UP, he realize he done with

all this flag waving nonsense and just gotta
get his ass outta there STAT.

Life is fragile as fu**, and it
goes by like (Sparky snaps) that. So live
it up, padna.

And there ain’t no better way to
start livin large than sportin my swag and

hittin dat subscribe button. SPARKY SWEETS
LIVES. Peace!

title: Catch-22 - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.author: Eiko J

comments.text:
Catch-22 has always been my favorite classical book. It proves you don't 
have to have an extremely serious mood to get a serious point across. It 
makes me think of The Crucible if it was high on drugs. These days, the 
only books that seem to get respect seem like they're written by 
chronically depressed people who hate the world, but still decide to 
confine themselves to the limits of the world instead of expanding beyond 
those limits and actually doing something.﻿
comments.author: Ari Liu

comments.text:
Hiw can you not be confined to the limits of the world? It is all we have. 
Perhaps I'm being too accepting in that thought. Perhaps you were 
referencing something more specific.
Anyway, Catch-22 is absolutely hilarious, but it's, to me, funny in the way 
that you can't handle something; funny in the way that you laugh because 
what else is there to do as such a spectator in the midst of such desperate 
characters? It is not the kind of humor that always brings us together, I 
believe. It's of a more melancholic breed.
comments.author: MelancholyImbecilism

comments.text:
True enough. I hate how comedy is considered a low art, when tragedy is 
seen as the pinnacle of literary art somehow. Technically, it's easy to 
make people cry, but it's much harder to make them laugh. Especially with 
such a difficult subject matter as the one in Catch-22. Yet it's a really 
funny book.

comments.text:
This guy definitely has his own style and deserves props for the time and 
effort that he puts in to these videos, but the language that this guy uses 
is completely uncalled for. I understand that he is trying to summarize the 
story up and give it a modern touch, but it seems that it could be done 
without all of the filthy language.  I think I would rather read a long 
boring book than to watch this guys version of the story. On that note, 
everyone has a different opinion and it seems by reading all of the 
comments below that people seem to relate to this guy and think that he 
does a great job.  This is just not my style and I would prefer to read the 
book or watch the play.﻿

comments.text:
That was one of the catch 22s. While he was alive she didnt care for him, 
but the moment he died she was madly in love, but had he survived and 
returned she would again become indifferent. So in order for him to get 
what he wanted most he needed to die and stay dead.

comments.author: Thompson lives

comments.text:
Nice job (although you might have given people a Spoiler Alert about 
Sweden.)  Just for reference, the non-linear timeline (the author jumping 
back and forth in time) of the plot that flows through the book is referred 
to as "stream of consciousness." 
    One interesting side note about the author, Joseph Heller, is that he 
never served one day in the military.  Some people thought Heller was 
writing a protest commentary about Viet Nam when the book first came out, 
but Heller states that using the background of war was simply a convenient 
metaphor for modern life.  Still many who have served in the military (like 
me) say the book couldn't be closer to the truth. 
    Anyway, thanks for doing my favorite book, Mr. Thug.  We'll get into 
Nately's whore some other time. Peace.﻿
